title: Quiz: FQE July 2021 - Community Health
description: Final Qualifying Examination for Diploma in Clinical Medicine & Surgery - Community Health (July 2021)

questions.question: The 2019 Novel Corona Virus was first identified in:
questions.explanation: The 2019 Novel Coronavirus (SARS-CoV-2) was first identified in Wuhan, Hubei Province, China, in December 2019.
questions.hint: It originated in Hubei province.

questions.question: Which element of Primary Health Care (PHC) was incorporated AFTER the Alma-Ata declaration?
questions.explanation: The original 8 elements of Alma Ata (1978) included Nutrition, Immunization, and Water/Sanitation. Mental Health (and Dental Health) were often added later in national policies.
questions.hint: This element deals with psychological well-being.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is TRUE about the role of cultural practices, values, and beliefs?

options.text: They are counterproductive and reduce accessibility of the health services by the community
They provide opportunities for increasing the community's ability to effectively access health services
They are the cause of majority of the diseases in the community
They reduce the community's ability to utilize health services

questions.explanation: In the context of health utilization barriers, cultural practices (like FGM or preference for herbalists) are often cited as factors that reduce the utilization of modern health services.
questions.hint: Think about how traditional beliefs might conflict with modern medicine.

questions.question: The health promotion approach that aims at increasing an individual's knowledge about the causes of health and illness is:
questions.explanation: The Educational or Behaviour change approach focuses on providing information (knowledge) to individuals to help them make informed choices.
questions.hint: It focuses on the individual's actions.

questions.question: The sustainability of community health programs will be realized if there is:

options.text: Improved relationships between families and community members
Effective mechanisms for disease prevention and control for the population
Empowerment of all members of the community to realize their rights and responsibilities
Improved and adequate disease surveillance activities for population

questions.explanation: Community empowerment and ownership are the cornerstones of sustainability.
questions.hint: The community must feel they own the program.

questions.question: Which one of the following is NOT a symptom of vitamin A deficiency?
questions.explanation: Malformation of long bones (Rickets) is caused by Vitamin D deficiency. Vitamin A deficiency causes eye problems and skin issues.
questions.hint: This symptom relates to rickets, not night blindness.

questions.question: Concerning mid upper arm circumference (MUAC):

richContent.content: MUAC Tapes: Red (<11.5cm), Yellow (11.5-12.5cm), Green (>12.5cm).

options.text: Severe malnutrition is defined by MUAC < 11.5cm in children aged 6-59 months
It is the circumference of the right upper arm
It is measured at the mid-point between the hip of the shoulder and the wrist joint
It is used to access stunting

questions.explanation: Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM) is defined as MUAC < 11.5cm. It is measured on the LEFT arm, between the shoulder tip and elbow (not wrist), and assesses wasting, not stunting.
questions.hint: Think about the red zone on the tape.

questions.question: Criteria for an adequate house include:

options.text: It should have an in-built toilet
It should have adequate light and ventilation
It should have a cemented floor

questions.explanation: Adequate ventilation and lighting are physiological needs for healthful housing to prevent respiratory infections and accidents.
questions.hint: Fresh air and visibility are key.

questions.question: Sullage means:

options.text: Solid and liquid excreta of animals

questions.explanation: Sullage (Grey water) is waste water from kitchens/baths without fecal matter. Sewage (Black water) contains excreta.
questions.hint: It is also known as 'Grey Water'.

questions.question: Aeration of water during waste water treatment primarily removes:
questions.explanation: Aeration adds air to strip out dissolved gases like CO2 and H2S (which cause bad tastes and odors) and oxidizes metals.
questions.hint: It improves taste and smell by removing gases.

questions.question: Which of the following is a water-related (water-based vector) disease?
questions.explanation: Malaria is water-related because its vector (mosquito) needs water to breed. Dysentery, Polio, and Hep A are water-borne (ingested).
questions.hint: The vector breeds in water.

questions.question: The technique that utilizes probability sampling is:
questions.explanation: Stratified sampling is a random (probability) method. Snowball, Purposive, and Convenience are non-probability methods.
questions.hint: It involves dividing the population into strata.

questions.question: Which of the following is a measure of dispersion?
questions.explanation: Standard Deviation measures the spread (dispersion) of data. Mean, Median, and Mode are measures of central tendency.
questions.hint: It shows how 'spread out' the data is.

questions.question: Sensitivity is the ability of a screening test to identify:
questions.explanation: Sensitivity is the ability to correctly identify those WITH the disease (True Positives). Specificity identifies True Negatives.
questions.hint: Ideally, 100% sensitivity means zero false negatives.

questions.question: The stage of a disease in which signs and symptoms usually occur is known as:

options.text: Stage of recovery, disability or death

questions.explanation: The clinical stage is when the disease manifests with recognizable signs and symptoms.
questions.hint: It's when you go to the 'clinic' because you feel sick.

questions.question: The sub-clinical stage of a disease begins with/at:

options.text: Pathological changes which occur without individual being aware of them
Onset of symptoms and signs of the disease

questions.explanation: The sub-clinical (or latency) stage involves pathological changes happening in the body after exposure but before symptoms appear.
questions.hint: The disease is there, but hidden (sub = under).

questions.question: Infectivity refers to:

options.text: The proportion of exposed persons who become infected
The proportion of infected individuals who develop clinically apparent disease
The proportion of clinically apparent cases are severe or fatal
The proportion of exposed persons who are asymptomatic

questions.explanation: Infectivity is the ability of an agent to invade and multiply (Exposed -> Infected). Pathogenicity is Infected -> Sick.
questions.hint: The ability to 'infect'.

questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding factors of disease causation is FALSE?

options.text: Enabling factors assist in the development of a disease e.g. socio-economic status
Precipitating factors are associated with immediate exposure to the disease agent
Reinforcing factors create a state of susceptibility so that the host becomes vulnerable
Risk factors increase the chances of an individual to develop a disease

questions.explanation: Statement C describes 'Predisposing' factors. Reinforcing factors typically strengthen or perpetuate a behavior (like peer pressure or rewards).
questions.hint: Look for the definition of 'Reinforcing' vs 'Predisposing'.

questions.question: The first step in investigating a disease outbreak (from the options provided) is:

options.text: Confirming the existence of the outbreak
Finding cases systematically and recording information

questions.explanation: Standard steps often list 'Prepare for field work', then 'Verify Diagnosis' or 'Confirm Outbreak'. Verification of diagnosis ensures you aren't investigating a false alarm.
questions.hint: You need to know WHAT you are dealing with first.

questions.question: The systematic and on-going assessment of all aspects of occurrence and spread of diseases that are pertinent to effective control is known as:
questions.explanation: Disease Surveillance is the ongoing, systematic collection, analysis, and interpretation of health data.
questions.hint: Keeping a constant watch.

questions.question: According to the WHO ICIDH model, the sequence with which a disease turns into a handicap is:

richContent.content: Concept: Pathology → Organ Level → Person Level → Society Level.

questions.explanation: The sequence is: Disease (Pathology) -> Impairment (Organ function) -> Disability (Person's ability) -> Handicap (Social disadvantage).
questions.hint: D-I-D-H.

questions.question: The last measure of severity of a disease is:
questions.explanation: Case Fatality Rate (CFR) measures the proportion of diagnosed cases that die, reflecting the virulence/severity.
questions.hint: It measures how likely the disease is to kill you once you have it.

questions.question: Regarding population pyramids, which statement is TRUE?

options.text: A change in fertility rate, mortality rate and migration are considered the only demographic dynamics that can directly affect the size, distribution and composition of any population
The concave sides (curved in) of a population pyramid indicates low death rates
The convex sides (curved out) of a population pyramid indicates high death rates
A square-like structure suggests a rapid population growth

questions.explanation: Fertility, Mortality, and Migration are the three components of population change. Concave sides indicate HIGH death rates (rapid drop off). Square structure indicates STABLE/SLOW growth.
questions.hint: The three components of demography.

questions.question: Push factors of migration include:
questions.explanation: Push factors are negative aspects (Conflict, Famine) that force people to leave. Pull factors (Jobs, Safety) attract them.
questions.hint: Reasons that force you to leave.

questions.question: In a study starting in 1999, 800 adults were asked about alcohol consumption. Cancer occurrence between 2009 and 2019 was studied in this group. This is an example of:
questions.explanation: The study started with a group (Cohort) and followed them forward in time from exposure (1999) to outcome (2009-2019).
questions.hint: Following a group forward in time.

questions.question: The principle of ethics that guards against avoidable harm to the subject is:
questions.explanation: Non-maleficence means 'Do No Harm'.
questions.hint: The Latin term for 'do no bad'.

questions.question: A vulnerable group in workplace improvement includes:
questions.explanation: Casual workers lack job security, benefits, and often PPE, making them more vulnerable than permanent staff.
questions.hint: Workers without job security.

questions.question: Regarding non-communicable diseases (NCDs) in Kenya:

options.text: NCDs are also known as infectious diseases
Kenya has added stroke, musculoskeletal diseases and accidents/injuries to its list of importance
The WHO prioritized five main NCDs include malaria

questions.explanation: Kenya's strategy includes injuries and other conditions beyond the standard WHO 'Big 4' (CV, Cancer, Diabetes, Resp). Malaria is infectious.
questions.hint: Kenya recognizes injuries as a major NCD burden.

questions.question: Which statement is true regarding Cholera?

options.text: It is caused by a virus
The main sign is severe bloody diarrhea
Rehydration and electrolyte replacement reduces case fatality rates

questions.explanation: Prompt rehydration is the cornerstone of treatment. Cholera is bacterial (Vibrio), causes watery stool (not bloody), and is diagnosed via stool culture.
questions.hint: Treatment focuses on replacing lost fluids.

questions.question: Athlete's foot can be prevented by:

options.text: Drying your feet gently but thoroughly after washing

questions.explanation: Fungi thrive in moisture. Keeping feet dry, especially between toes, prevents infection.
questions.hint: Fungus loves dampness.

questions.question: An INDIRECT cause of maternal mortality is:
questions.explanation: Direct causes (Sepsis, Eclampsia) result from obstetric complications. Indirect causes (Anemia, Malaria) are pre-existing conditions worsened by pregnancy.
questions.hint: A condition the mother might have had before pregnancy.

questions.question: When using the 5-TT (Tetanus toxoid) schedule in ANC, which rule applies?

options.text: TT2 should not be given less than 4 weeks after TT1
Schedule should be restarted if interval is short

questions.explanation: The minimum interval between TT1 and TT2 is 4 weeks. Doses should not be given sooner than the minimum interval.
questions.hint: Think about the minimum gap between the first two shots.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a sign of good attachment when breastfeeding?

options.text: More areola seen above than below the mouth

questions.explanation: For good attachment, the lower lip should be turned OUTWARD (everted). Turning inward indicates poor latch.
questions.hint: The lip should flange out like a fish.

questions.question: Which of these is a LIVE ATTENUATED vaccine?
questions.explanation: Measles, BCG, and OPV are live attenuated vaccines. Tetanus is a toxoid. Hep B is recombinant.
questions.hint: It contains a weakened version of the actual virus.

questions.question: Regarding immunization schedules:

options.text: Pneumococcal vaccine is given at 6, 10 and 14 weeks
Rota virus vaccine is given at 10 and 14 weeks
Measles vaccine is given at 9 and 18 months on the Right arm

questions.explanation: PCV-10 (Pneumococcal) is given at 6, 10, and 14 weeks. IPV is at 14 weeks. Rota is 6 and 10 weeks. Measles is usually Left arm.
questions.hint: PCV follows the DPT schedule.

questions.question: Mental health can be promoted through:
questions.explanation: Physical exercise and well-being are strongly linked to positive mental health ('Mens sana in corpore sano').
questions.hint: A healthy body supports a healthy mind.

questions.question: Schizophrenia is best described as:

options.text: A mental disorder of altered mood
A severe mental disorder with personality deterioration, hallucinations and delusions
A disorder caused by medical conditions inducing brain dysfunction
A state of tension and apprehension (Anxiety)

questions.explanation: Schizophrenia is a psychosis characterized by loss of touch with reality (delusions/hallucinations).
questions.hint: It involves a break from reality.

questions.question: Drug addiction/dependence:

options.text: Psychotherapy has no role in treatment

questions.explanation: Addiction is recognized medically as a chronic, relapsing brain disease affecting the reward system.
questions.hint: It is a medical condition, not just a moral failing.

questions.question: Regarding Catha Edulis (Khat/Miraa):

options.text: It has no psycho stimulant effect
It produces euphoria, suppresses appetite, and causes alertness
Induced psychosis is distinguishable from schizophrenia

questions.explanation: Khat contains Cathinone (amphetamine-like), causing stimulation, euphoria, and loss of appetite.
questions.hint: It keeps you awake and happy initially.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a key objective of the Kenya Health Policy 2014-2030?

options.text: Halt and reverse the rising burden of NCDs
Provide exposure to health risk factors

questions.explanation: The objective is to MINIMIZE exposure to risk factors, not provide it.
questions.hint: Look for the option that sounds harmful.

questions.question: Select the factors that determine health (Determinants of Health):
questions.explanation: Health is determined by biology, environment, lifestyle, socio-economics, and health services.
questions.hint: Select the scientific determinants.

questions.question: Outline the services offered at Level One (Community Services) in Kenya:
questions.explanation: Level 1 focuses on promotion, prevention, and basic minor ailment treatment by CHVs. Surgery is Level 3+.
questions.hint: Think of what a Community Health Volunteer does.

questions.question: Select diseases transmitted by mosquitoes:
questions.explanation: Malaria, Yellow Fever, Dengue, Chikungunya, and Filariasis are mosquito-borne. Typhoid is water-borne.
questions.hint: Typhoid comes from dirty water/food.

questions.question: Arrange the stages of the Natural History of Disease in order:

items.text: Stage of Recovery, Disability, or Death

questions.explanation: Disease progresses from Exposure -> Incubation -> Symptoms -> Outcome.
questions.hint: Start with being healthy but exposed.

questions.question: Identify the roles of a clinician in disease surveillance:
questions.explanation: Clinicians must detect, record, report, sample, and treat cases.
questions.hint: All the active steps in managing and reporting a disease.

questions.question: Select MODIFIABLE risk factors for Non-Communicable Diseases (NCDs):
questions.explanation: Modifiable factors are behaviors you can change (diet, smoking). Non-modifiable are Age, Sex, Genetics.
questions.hint: Things you can choose to change.

questions.question: In an outbreak where 500 students out of 2000 became ill, calculate the Attack Rate percentage. (Enter the number only)
questions.hint: Divide 500 by 2000 and multiply by 100.

questions.question: Match the workplace hazard type with its example:
questions.explanation: Physical (Energy), Chemical (Substances), Biological (Living), Ergonomic (Body), Psychosocial (Mind).
questions.hint: Match the nature of the hazard.

questions.question: Select the major methods for controlling communicable diseases:

richContent.content: Control Strategy: Interventions must target the links in the Chain of Infection.

questions.explanation: Control involves 1. Source control, 2. Breaking transmission, 3. Protecting the host.
questions.hint: Select the three valid public health strategies.
